intro: Ampacus tetragona, commonly known as the four-angled grass, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as grasslands and wetlands. Its leaves are narrow and often have a distinctive four-angled cross-section, giving it its common name. Ampacus tetragona produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are typical of grasses.
